posts.cooked:
image 1515×530 31.5 KB We are using a raspberry pi 4 running photonvision, using this to power it, and when we drive the bot the camera will stop working (I assume its browning out) and then it will take some time and reboot and work again. PhotonVision says that it’s throttling the CPU because of low voltage. I’m not sure why this is happening?

image 1515×530 31.5 KB

image 1515×530 31.5 KB

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Hmmm. I can’t say I’ve used that particular device to power a Pi before.

That status is generated from reading the result of running vcgencmd get_throttled to ask the pi if/why it’s not running at full capacity.

The undervoltage threshold happens at a supply voltage of about 4.6v - you can measure it across the pins on the pi if you want to double check.

Overall though, I think your bigger issue is this:

image 685×978 83.9 KB

image 685×978 83.9 KB

image 685×978 83.9 KB

It’s pretty frequent for battery voltage to dip below 10v when you put some load on it. It only takes a short period of low voltage to reset the pi.

TL;DR consider a different supply. This page has a lot of useful info.

link_counts.title: Dealing with the Low Voltage Warning on the Raspberry Pi - Pi My Life Up

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I’m on this team, we figured it out. The pi wanted 6v not 5v

posts.name: Jansen joss
posts.cooked: We faced this same issue with our pi 5 and buck converter. We ended up going with a power bank because we knew even through the brownout safety protocols or voltage dip our pi wouldn’t reset. After making this swap we didn’t loose our April tag vision or driver cams. Biggest thing is to make sure the power bank your buying is legal and has a high enough power output. Our original power bank ended up not having high enough power output due to the misleading Amazon pages. Our main mentor who does purchasing is not a technical mentor and bought a power bank that was Advertised as “the same” but had measured their ratings in a different way then most name brand power banks.

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked: Please note that the input is speced at 10-32 volts.  During high current demands, the robot battery can get down to 6 volts for short periods that do not invoke RoboRio brownout protection.  Between 6 and 10 volts this power supply will drop out or the output voltage will fall below 5 volts.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!

link_counts.title: FRC 3061 Huskie Robotics - 2024 Season Build Thread

posts.name: JohnRRRR
posts.cooked:
Jansenj07:

We ended up going with a power bank because we knew even through the brownout safety protocols or voltage dip our pi wouldn’t reset. After making this swap we didn’t loose our April tag vision

There is a setting you may have to update on the pi  5 ( usb_max_current_enable)  in config.txt with some power supplies to get full power on the USB ports and we saw similar low power warnings before updating it. Apparently this does not apply to the pi 4.

When I was setting up the rpi for our team earlier this season, I was also running into low voltage issues. We fixed it by getting a usb cable that comes with each sparkmax and connecting it to the ctre voltage regulator module in a 5V, 2A port. The vrm then also connects to the pdh at the 12v input slot

Here is the vrm link

Voltage Regulator Module

Price: USD 49.99

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: We tried this, but it still gave us low voltage warnings

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: What Pi do you have? Many require more than 2A

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I believe it is a pi 4, but it might be one of the sub models. I remember the docs saying 5v 3a

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: The VRM is 1.5 A continuous and 2 A occasional peak. My team powered the camera from a powered USB hub to take some load off of the VRM /RPi and we got few but not none low power warnings.

posts.name: CJ Hill
posts.cooked: We previously used the exact same 12V-5V DC DC converter listed by the OP.  We found it off of a CD post maybe two years ago that I can’t find any more. It was a mistake to use this, but hard to detect because at home in practice we don’t have a full field so we almost never used the bot hard enough to get a brownout.  However, in competion, we get dips to 8V all the time (not a true stage 1/2 RIO brownout, but easily enough to starve this converter) so the pis would reboot and we’d lose our video feed, camera telemetry, etc. We fixed it by going to the much better polulu converter (50-5.5V input, 5V output) that we learned about from this post .  I have two pi 4Bs running off of it with two cameras on each of them and no problems with power outages since switching to the new power supply.  I checked the current in each pi and even with two cameras on they pretty much only pull 1.2A or so, so except on boot for our purposes they don’t actually need that much current - I think they do when you start to power other things out the GPIO pins, but our USB cameras aren’t that power hungry.
